Line 30: Line 30:
==1989-1990: Early work and founding of CTUWS==
==1989-1990: Early work and founding of CTUWS==
â
Abbas was a steel-worker at a steel mill.<ref>http://blog.aflcio.org/2007/06/26/labor-support-organization-banned-after-strike-actions/</ref>
+
In 1989 when Abbas was 34 years old<ref>http://www.wac-maan.org.il/en/article__53</ref>, he has been working for 14 years<ref>http://www.wac-maan.org.il/en/article__53</ref> at a steel mill.<ref>http://blog.aflcio.org/2007/06/26/labor-support-organization-banned-after-strike-actions/</ref>
Abbas began his organizing work under the [[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak regime]], when unions were dominated by the state-approved [[Egyptian Trade Union Federation]] (ETUF). He participated in an August 1989 strike at the Iron and Steel Company plant in [[Helwan]], Egypt. 19,000 workers went on strike for wage increases and a meal during work. They were met by 10,000 riot police with rubber bullets and tear gas.<ref>http://blog.aflcio.org/2007/06/26/labor-support-organization-banned-after-strike-actions/</ref> Security forces stormed the plant, killing one, injuring one hundred, and arresting hundreds.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/may/14/world/fg-activist14 |title=Problems In Egypt | Unions tap into public ire in Egypt - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2008-05-14 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaelmoore.com/words/must-read/statement-kamal-abbas |title='We Stand With You as You Stood With Us': Statement to Workers of Wisconsin by Kamal Abbas of Egypt's Centre for Trade Unions and Workers Services |publisher=MichaelMoore.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref name="aflcio2007">{{cite web|url=http://blog.aflcio.org/2007/06/26/labor-support-organization-banned-after-strike-actions/ |title=Egyptian Labor-Support Organization Banned After Strike Actions | AFL-CIO NOW BLOG |publisher=Blog.aflcio.org |date=2007-06-26 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
Abbas began his organizing work under the [[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak regime]], when unions were dominated by the state-approved [[Egyptian Trade Union Federation]] (ETUF). He participated in an August 1989 strike at the Iron and Steel Company plant in [[Helwan]], Egypt. 19,000 workers went on strike for wage increases and a meal during work. They were met by 10,000 riot police with rubber bullets and tear gas.<ref>http://blog.aflcio.org/2007/06/26/labor-support-organization-banned-after-strike-actions/</ref> Security forces stormed the plant, killing one, injuring one hundred, and arresting hundreds.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/may/14/world/fg-activist14 |title=Problems In Egypt | Unions tap into public ire in Egypt - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2008-05-14 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaelmoore.com/words/must-read/statement-kamal-abbas |title='We Stand With You as You Stood With Us': Statement to Workers of Wisconsin by Kamal Abbas of Egypt's Centre for Trade Unions and Workers Services |publisher=MichaelMoore.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref name="aflcio2007">{{cite web|url=http://blog.aflcio.org/2007/06/26/labor-support-organization-banned-after-strike-actions/ |title=Egyptian Labor-Support Organization Banned After Strike Actions | AFL-CIO NOW BLOG |publisher=Blog.aflcio.org |date=2007-06-26 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
